entry.title: Do Solar Panels Work on Cloudy Days?
entry.summary:
Solar panels are known for generating their power from daylight - but do they work as productively in cloudy weather? Learn more here!

More
entry.content:
With the winter months fast approaching, the weather will soon become more unpredictable. Not only will the days become shorter and darker, but there are bound to be more clouds in the sky.

As solar panels draw their energy from the sun, it is a common misconception that they don’t work in cloudy or overcast conditions. However, solar panels don’t need direct sunlight to produce electricity, meaning that they will continue to work, even in adverse weather conditions.

 

How Do Solar Panels Produce Electricity?

Solar panels use photovoltaic (PV) cells to absorb daylight and generate electrical currents to power appliances both in the home and on the go. Solar panels are made using semi-conducting substances, such as silicone, that help convert light into electricity in a more efficient way.

When light is absorbed by solar panels, electron particles move to create energy. This is why solar panels generally create more electricity in stronger sunlight. For instance, when the sky is clear, the most energy will be produced around midday as this is when the sun is at its highest.

However, this does not mean that energy cannot be absorbed by solar panels when the sun is not visible.

 

How Do Solar Panels Work on Cloudy Days?

As solar panels work by absorbing daylight rather than sunlight, they continue to produce electricity even on overcast days.

Although the productivity of solar panels is not as effective on cloudy days, they can still generate up to 25% of their usual output. Solar panels do not only absorb visible light, but also different wavelengths of light that pass through thick cloud.

In simple terms, as long as a shadow can be cast, solar panels can work effectively to generate electricity.

 

The ‘Edge-of-Cloud’ Effect

Clouds and shade can reduce the amount of energy solar panels produce, yet this is not always the case. Oftentimes, cloudy conditions can cause a higher output of electricity. This is due to a phenomenon called the ‘edge-of-cloud’ effect.

The effect is caused by the increase in irradiance, which results in more radiant energy being made. The reflection of the sun against passing clouds allows light to make contact with the solar panels causing higher outputs of energy to be generated.

Will Solar Panels Work in the Shade?

Many factors, including natural causes, can mean that shade will decrease the amount of energy solar panels generate.

Although solar panel systems are engineered to prevent shading from compromising the production of energy, this is dependent on the individual solar technology – in particular, microinverters.

Depending on the placement of the microinverters, the panels will be affected by shading in different ways. For example, if the wires are connected to one inverter, the whole solar panel system will be affected. This will mean that the shaded panel causes the others to underperform, therefore preventing energy from passing through to the central inverter.

Alternatively, if the panels have their own individual microinverters, the panel which is shaded will be the only one affected, rather than the whole system.

This is why the overall impact of energy production will be less severe when there is multiple inverters.

 

What Other Conditions Affect the Efficiency of Solar Panels?

Other conditions such as the time of day and alternative weather conditions can also affect the efficiency of solar panels and their production of energy.

 

During the Night

Although solar panels require daylight to generate electricity, certain systems will include a backup battery storage. This backup battery allows solar panels to store excess energy from throughout the day, which can then be used during the night.  

 

Fog

Similar to cloudy and overcast weather, foggy conditions can affect solar production. However, the panels are still able to capture some energy from the daylight.

Fog typically burns off throughout the day, especially during the morning. This means that by midday, the solar panels will be performing to their usual capacity, providing that the sun has returned to view.

It is estimated that solar panels operate at 50% of their normal efficiency when the weather is foggy, this is more than both dense cloud and overcast conditions.

 

How Effective Are Solar Panel Systems?

Whether on the go or at home, the amount of energy which is needed varies between different people and their routines. However, in order to make the most out of solar panel systems, it is important to consider their placement. It is recommended that the panels are placed on a 30-degree tilt in an open space to ensure that sufficient energy is being produced.

If these factors are taken into account, they can have profound effects on electricity bills. For example, utility company Eon found that a 12-panel solar system could generate enough electricity in a year to help save a household over 534€ on electricity bills!

 

Making the Most of Your Solar Panels

Although adverse weather conditions can affect the productivity of solar panels, they don’t completely count out their efficiency. While it is clear that solar panels require daylight to generate energy, there are plenty of solutions to making the most of your systems, even on the cloudiest days!

When taking into consideration the different set-up requirements for solar panels in regard to local weather patterns, it is simpler than ever to naturally generate electricity.

entry.title: Portable Solar Panels: What Are They & How Do They Work?
entry.summary:
Looking for more information about portable solar panels, exactly? Well don't worry, we've got you covered.

More
entry.content:
With all the power you need to fuel your next adventure, portable solar panels use all the same technology as the panels on your home, albeit in a much more compact size.

However, unlike solar panels that you might install on your roof which are set in a fixed, rigid frame and sealed under glass, portable panels are often encased in a protective sleeve, designed to be folded and transported.

Discover the immense power of portable solar panels and exactly how they work here at BLUETTI.

What Are Portable Solar Panels?

There’s no doubt that solar panels for households and businesses have become a common sight across Europe and beyond, with entire neighborhoods decorated with solar systems to help reduce energy costs. However, one solar niche was not addressed until recently, with portable solar panels now allowing solar energy to be transported anywhere at any time with ease.  

Whether you’re camping with friends, travelling in your campervan, or fuelling your home during a power cut, portable solar panels can provide you with the energy you need. They’re exactly what their name suggests: small sized panels designed to work on the go – priced at around half of what it would cost to have solar panels installed on your roof.

Unsurprisingly, portable solar panels are considered to have a limited power output when compared to fixed solar systems. However, our leading solar specialists at Bluetti have developed a range of powerful, portable solar panels alongside portable power stations – designed to generate energy whenever and wherever you need it.

 

How Do They Work?

When you use portable solar panels, they keep your deep-cycle batteries charged to provide power to electrical appliances. Without the need for traditional power sources such as generators, you’re free to power your appliances whenever you wish without requiring a ready supply of fuel for continued operation.

Portable solar panels are made up of photovoltaic cells that capture and convert solar power into electricity. The portable panels are then attached to one another and connected to a battery to store the energy produced by the sun. This power can then be used to fuel electronics in the same way you would use battery power.

 

The Benefits of Portable Solar Power

With a large variety of portable solar panels available for all budgets and power needs, solar technology offers numerous benefits including high efficiency and low maintenance. However, the most important benefit of portable solar panels, and the reason why most people purchase them, is the remarkable return on investment they offer.

High Quality Solar Cells

In most cases, as with the portable solar panels available at Bluetti, portable solar panels are monocrystalline, giving them a significantly high efficiency rating.

During the manufacturing process, the silicon is formed into bars and later cut into wafers of monocrystalline cells. Interestingly, the term ‘monocrystalline’ implies the use of single-crystal silicon. Due to the single-crystal silicon, electrons move more freely and as a result, provide more power from the panel to the device being charged.

 

Versatile

Thanks to their portability, these solar panels are typically used by hikers, campers, travellers, or anyone who needs an electricity supply when not able to access grid power. However, since they come in numerous sizes, they have several other uses too.

While most portable solar panels are not ideal for fixed use, it’s possible for panels to form a portable power system, designed to perform on rooftops of buildings as well as on top of vehicles.

Alternatively, portable solar panels can be used to facilitate camping trips, charge your phone on the go, or rectify a power outage, providing a multi-use system to ease energy problems.

 

Weatherproof

With specialist coating and protective materials, portable solar panels are designed with campers in mind with the ability to withstand any scratches and watersplash. Perfect for camping, fishing, hiking and much more, portable solar systems can be used in any weather conditions – charging even on wet and windy days.

 

Money Saving

When thinking about saving electricity with solar panels, you might also think about which appliances and machines you can power with portable solar panels and generators. From large appliances such as refrigerators, washing machines and air conditioners to smaller electronic devices, consider utilising your solar investment with portable solutions.

 

Renewable Energy

As climate change and global warming continue to impact our Earth, causing extreme weather, rising temperatures, melting glaciers and further devastation, the search for more sustainable solutions has never been more important.  

Portable solar power not only produces renewable and reliable electricity from sunlight, but also lowers the emissions of harmful greenhouse gases emitted by traditional energy backup systems. Because of this, you don’t have to worry about the environmental impact of using gasoline to power your camping gear and electrical appliances.

entry.title: Can you Charge Electric Cars with Solar Panels?
entry.summary:
Can you charge electric cars with solar panels?   Yes, but it's not easy or cost-effective. Read on to find out more.

More
entry.content:
Electric vehicles (EVs) continue to grow in popularity, with sales of diesel and petrol vehicles on the decline.

EVs do not produce any toxic emissions meaning a greener and cleaner driving experience. However, driving an EV does not necessarily make for a completely climate-friendly driving experience.

If your electric car is charged with mains electricity, this energy will have been generated – at least in part - through the burning of fossil fuels. There is no getting away from the fact that coal and gas are essential in meeting the EU’s current power demands.

One way to ensure you’re using a renewable energy source is to generate your own! For many, solar energy is the most suitable and practical alternative. But what is the reality of powering your car using solar energy?

How Many Solar Panels Do I Need to Charge my EV Car?

The answer depends on a few different factors, including what kind of EV you have, how many miles you drive and how much sun you get too!

For an average-sized EV battery, 8-12 Solar panels usually generate enough energy to fully charge your car. However, if you want to know the optimum number of panels for your needs, a few calculations may help.

First you must calculate the daily energy (kWh) that your EV requires to fully charge. The below formula takes into consideration how many miles you drive and your car’s power consumption.

Then, use the below formula to calculate the amount of power (DC size) you require from your photovoltaic (PV) system. Factoring in peak hours of sunlight allows for an accurate estimate.

Lastly, you must divide the total DC size by the generation capacity of your solar panels. The result will give you a good indication of how many solar panels you will require to charge your vehicle. However, it is not a replacement for professional advise!

How Long Does It Take to Charge an Electric Car with Solar Panels?

The answer to this question depends on a number of factors, such as how many miles you drive daily, where you live, your EV’s battery size and the size and efficiency of your solar system.

Typically, it takes between 30 minutes and 12 hours to charge the average EV.

Let’s use an example.

The Nissan Leaf is one of the best-selling pure-EVs in the EU and for this reason we’re using it in our calculations below.

A second-generation Nissan Leaf has a typical 4 kW solar installation and a 40kWh battery. This means it would take around 18 hours 30 minutes to fully charge the car through a regular wall plug. Understandably, this is not a convenient or indeed viable option for many!

However, a specially-installed EV charging point allows for quicker charging; you can expect a full charge to take around 7 hours. Whilst this option incurs an additional financial outlay, the convenience of a faster charge is worth the cost for many!

 

How Do You Charge Your Electric Car Using Energy from Your Solar Panels?

There are a few things to consider before you start charging your EV with solar.

Installing a home charging unit and PV inverter is necessary for an efficient solar charging experience. The inverter converts direct currents (DC) to alternating currents (AC), generating electricity from the energy being stored.

Even with the growing use of electric vehicles, many people are worried about not having a charging port close to their home. A home solar charging unit is the most convenient option, allowing you to rely entirely on renewable sources too!

A home battery storage solution is also something to consider, especially if you want to charge your car overnight. This allows solar energy to be stored without going to waste. It is a common solution for those who use their car consistently throughout the day and cannot find time for a quick charge.

Check out our collection of home battery backups here.

Is It Worth Charging Your Car Using Solar Energy?

Most definitely.

People can be deterred by the initial upfront costs. However EU schemes are available to reduce the financial barrier to entry.

Ultimately, charging with solar energy allows for the cheapest, cleanest and most convenient driving experience. Using a completely renewable resource, charging your car with solar reduces your carbon footprint far beyond any other charging method.

Charging your car with solar energy allows for flexibility and convenience; you can even charge your car from the comfort of your own home.

If your solar panels generate enough energy, you might even be able to power both your house and car with them! Furthermore, solar systems often last between 25-30 years. So, once your energy saving has paid for your PV system, you could be charging your EV for free for a further 17 years or more!

The benefits of charging your EV with solar energy is almost endless!

 

Final Thoughts

In summary, to charge your EV using solar power, you will need a large PV system - ideally 3000 watts or more. If you want to reap all the benefits of solar energy by powering your other household appliances too, you will need a larger PV system - 15,000 watts plus.

Our solar generators provide the perfect solution. With systems suitable for all eventualities, Bluetti helps to ensure that you can power your EV and home in a convenient and efficient manner.

entry.title: What to Consider When Buying Camping Solar Panels?
entry.summary:
Are you going camping soon? Read more to find solar panels for camping that are right for your needs.

More
entry.content:
Camping provides a much-needed break from hectic day to day life, a chance to reconnect with nature and the opportunity to sleep under the stars.

We all have devices which are important to us, not just for comfort and connection but also for safety; we need to keep them charged.

The best solar panels for camping can offer an eco-friendly, clean, and efficient power supply. Whether you stay in a vehicle where panels can be fixed, or camp with a backpack and tent where portability is key, camping solar panels enable you to charge devices and appliances in an eco-friendly and efficient way.

Finding a solar panel that is right for your needs can be challenging. What you use it for will determine which is the best and most efficient portable solar panel for your camping needs.

The Top Five Things to Look for When Buying Camping Solar Panels

Wattage

Wattage is very important when considering your purchase. If you simply need to keep a phone or camera charged whilst camping, you'll only need a small charger, but if you're going to power more or bigger appliances, you'll need panels with a higher energy output.

The bare minimum you should look for is 2 Watts. This will allow you to charge small electronic items such as your mobile phone with around a 30-50% charge on a summer’s day.

If you are into photography and want to charge your DSLR or laptop, then you are going to need a little more power. 10 Watts will give you enough energy to charge both devices with around 1-3 charges a day in good sunlight.

If you want to charge multiple devices from your solar panel, then you will need 30+ Watts. This will allow you to charge things such as notebooks and cameras. 

The capacity to store energy for when you know the weather isn't going to be very sunny comes in the form of a solar panel with a battery. 

Types of Solar Panel

There are three main types of solar panels – monocrystalline, amorphous (thin-film) and crystalline. Monocrystalline panels are the most efficient but also the most expensive. Polycrystalline panels on the other hand, are less efficient but cost 30-50% less than its counterpart. Amorphus panels are significantly cheaper than both the other panels but are far less efficient. However, they are the most resilient and robust!

To ensure you are buying the most efficient solar panel, look for one made from monocrystalline solar cells. This type of high-end technology provides the highest efficiency and power capacity out of all types of solar panels.

BLUETTI only sells panels using this cell technology. Panels such as the BLUETTI PV200 Solar Panel can convert up to 23.4% of sunlight into solar energy making them the choice of serious campers.

Size and Weight

The higher the wattage, the more solar cells are needed, and this in turn increases the size of the panel. The power rating dictates the size and weight of the panel overall. A panel over 200 Watts will be too heavy for everyday camping.

Panels of up to around 100-watts are small and light enough to carry around with you.

There are three main types of portable monocrystalline or polycrystalline solar panels to choose from:

  • Rigid Solar Panel

Rigid solar panels are more suited to caravans or vehicles as they cannot be folded down to a compact size.

  • Lightweight Folding Solar Blanket

Folding solar blankets are perfect for travelers who are worried about space and weight. Whilst they are more expensive than panels, folding solar blankets offer added convenience. For example, they can be hung off awning, draped over your car or placed over your windscreen.

  • Freestanding Solar Panel

Freestanding solar panels can be moved and folded into a storable size. You can move them throughout the day to maximize sun exposure, making them super-efficient.

Consider Durability

Camping can be a rough activity, so you need to feel confident that your investment is going to last. Even the humble campsite poses risks to your new equipment - everything from potholes to gravel paths and the constant opening and closing of your panel will impact its lifespan.

Weather is a key factor and it’s essential to select a panel which is made of high-end materials. Bluetti PV350 Solar Panel is incredibly durable and splash-proof, boasting a handy kick stand which provides a quick and easy set up.

Cost and Warranty

Before you make your choice as to which type of panel to buy, it is advisable to draw up a cost to benefit analysis and consider your budget.

Although monocrystalline solar panels are more expensive than polycrystalline solar panels, they do offer a lot more energy for the price tag. Monocrystalline solar panels are made from superior grade silicon which has a single crystal structure, reducing resistance in the cells and allowing a better flow of electricity. This efficiency is one of the key advantages of monocrystalline solar panels.

It is possible to find cheap solar panels online. If you’re lucky, you might end up with one which doesn’t break the bank or break down mid-camping trip, but we would recommend buying your panels from a trusted, reputable supplier such as Bluetti. 

As with any major purchase, you want to spend more on carefully considered and sourced technology. Bluetti offer quality solar panels to suit your needs. Our solar panels offer a cost effective, durable, and reliable solution.

More important is the reassurance of our customer care and fantastic warranties.

You can rely on BLUETTI for your camping power!

entry.title: What Should I Pack for Glamping?
entry.summary:
What to Pack for Glamping? Here is a short guide to get you started on your glamping journey.

More
entry.content:
Camping isn’t for everyone. The idea of ‘roughing it’ deters many from bedding down in the great outdoors. However, there is a way to enjoy sleeping beneath the stars without the creepy-crawlies, tinned beans and leaking tents!  

Glamping is camping in style and luxury. You’ll find that glamping facilities and accommodation are much more comfortable than a sleeping bag and tent, allowing you to stay close to nature in comfort.  

But if glamping is so different to camping, then what on earth should you pack? Do you still need a sleeping bag and food supplies? Well, what goes on your glamping packing list depends on the accommodation you’ve booked, the activities you’ll be doing and the facilities available. Here is a short guide to get you started on your glamping journey.

What Can I Expect on My ‘Glamp Site’?

A traditional camping experience usually begins with you putting up a tent, struggling with guide ropes and then praying that it doesn’t leak or fall down. Glamping on the other hand sees you arrive at a fully functioning abode - usually a framed structure with electricity and hot running water.

There has been a surge in glamping sites all across the world over the last decade. They come in all shapes and sizes - from a yurt to a Shepherd’s hut, a treehouse to an Iron Age round house! Not every site is all inclusive; some provide everything you need; others may just be a step up from your basic camp site. Wherever you choose to rest your head, the location and type of lodging will dictate what you need to pack.

Most glamping sites provide the necessities; access to running water, toilets and even toilet roll. Some sites offer showers, hot tubs and even full-sized baths! However, very few will provide towels, shower gels or shampoos, so be sure to add them to the packing list.

Some glamp sites provide well-stocked kitchens with basic cooking ingredients and a delicious welcome hamper, whilst others provide the basic pots, pans and crockery. However, you shouldn’t necessarily expect anything to be provided.

You may be given logs and kindling to use on an open fire or log burner. However, other establishments may only provide a circle of bricks for you to make your own fire. Either way, we would recommend bringing a lighter or a box of matches with you.

It is useful to check your host’s website prior to packing to get an understanding of the facilities and what you’ll need to bring. If you’re unsure, then pick up the phone and ask. Unlike camp sites, the range of provisions and facilities at glamp sites vary hugely. This can make it difficult to know what you need to pack; you might need to take everything, or you may just need the clothes on your back. So always double check beforehand!

The Basics

There are some key considerations to make before you pack.

Food Storage

You may be provided with your own fridge or freezer. Or it may be communal which means it’s a good idea to bring a marker pen with you to write your name on all of your provisions. On the other hand, the site may not provide any food storage, so this is a key thing to consider when packing fresh food.

The Bear Necessities

The bathroom set up can vary widely when you’re glamping. You could have your own ensuite with a roll top bath, waterfall showers, and a log burning hot tub. Equally, there may be a hole in the ground, shared facilities or a compost toilet!

Knowing what the bathroom situation is will affect how you pack. You will certainly want something snuggly and warm to wear for those early hour toilet trips, especially if you have children!

Pack the basic toiletries; toilet roll, toothpaste, face cloth and towels. If you’re using an outdoor shower, it’s a good idea to bring organic soap, shampoo or an all-in-one hair and body wash. Your soap suds will end up in the ground so you need to use environmentally friendly products.

Many glamping sites take their environmental responsibilities very seriously and have a policy that bans the use of certain products. They often provide you with their own range of organic products to use. Check out if your glamping site has an online shop; you might be able to purchase their product range to take home with you.

Clothing

Pack as though you are going camping. Even if your site offers a more luxurious experience, you are still going to be outdoors most of the time. Most sites have a communal area for hanging out, cooking, singing songs and playing games. Pack warm clothing for the cold nights and practical, robust footwear is essential.  

Your essential glamping checklist:

  • Walking boots if you plan to do any outdoor hiking or woodland exploring
  • Waterproof shoes for the early morning walk to the facilities
  • Slip on shoes are useful for getting in and out of your accommodation with ease
  • A lightweight, waterproof and warm coat i
  • Hat and gloves
  • A cosy blanket
  • Warm clothes for bedtime; even treehouses get cold at night!
  • Flip flops or Crocs for communal bathrooms
  • A hot water bottle
  • An extra cardigan or jumper to wear on nights when the temperature suddenly drops
  • Bluetti portable power station

Food Glorious Food

Most glamping sites have basic kitchen set ups. You’re likely to find a gas stove and some pots and pans. Some sites offer catering as part of the package - barbecues and woodfired pizzas may be available, or even a restaurant or café!

If food isn’t offered as part of your glamping experience, bring food that is easy to prepare and cook. Pack a variety of meals that everyone can enjoy, and don’t forget to throw in a good supply of treats too!

 

Final Thoughts

If you’re unsure what to pack, simply get in touch with your site; they are the best people to advise you! Check where the nearest supermarket is too; this gives you a backup plan if you do forget something!

Ultimately, as long as you have the right clothes and shoes, you can usually pick up anything you are missing whilst you’re on holiday. Hopefully our glamping packing list means you won’t be packing the kitchen sink!

What’s Causing the European Energy Crisis?

Natural gas prices have been surging in Europe as demand increases globally. While this is happening with most commodities, it's been a larger problem with natural gas.

This is due to a global economic rebound as countries lift COVID-19 restrictions and fully reopen their economies. Markets are now competing as demand rises after the shock of the pandemic.

With Europe’s dependency on Russia for natural gas transportation, including crude oil and refined petroleum products, coal, steel, and iron, a current decline in supply has contributed to the energy crisis. As a result, the supply of these products has been slashed, causing their prices to soar.

An increased demand in Asia has also influenced energy prices, with numbers looking to inflate by 60% by 2040 – and around only 15% of this energy is renewable!

Globally, this ever-increasing demand will result in prices creeping up year after year, more so in times of crisis, as we have seen in the past few months.

entry.title: Solar Panel Maintenance: Why & How to Do It?
entry.summary:
How do you maintain a solar panel? Discover everything you need to know about solar panel maintenance right here at BLUETTI.

More
entry.content:
Homeowners who install solar power systems can receive numerous benefits: slashed electric bills, reduced carbon footprint, and potentially higher home values. With the capability to last you around 25-30 years, solar panels have plenty of time to get a return on your investment.

Unlike a boiler or washing machine, your solar panels are designed to work efficiently without continuous maintenance. However, to get the most value out of your solar panels and guarantee they last as long as they should, it’s important to properly maintain them. Discover everything you need to know about solar panel maintenance right here at Bluetti.

Solar Panel Cleaning: Is It Worth It?

Dust, sap, pollution and leaves provide just a few reasons to maintain and clean your solar panels. Essentially, dirty panels have the same impact on solar power systems as shading does, obstructing sunlight and affecting performance.

Impacting both your green energy generation and return on investment, we recommend for solar panel owners to have their system cleaned around 2-4 times per year. Alternatively, you may only need 1 cleaning per year if you live in an area with lots of rain to clear away dirt or debris.

If your panels are tilted, you’re fortunate enough that rainfall will naturally clear away accumulated debris. However, during summer months or extended periods without rain, it’s important to clean them manually – go ahead and try a garden hose or a leaf blower.

 

Do Solar Panels Require Maintenance?

Solar panels ordinarily require very little maintenance in order to function, meaning your solar investment is often upfront and stress-free. Despite this, there are generally three solar panel maintenance schedules to consider:

  • Cleaning:Periodic light cleaning to make sure dust, debris and leaves are not obstructing the sun’s rays.
  • Annual inspection:Once per year, hire an inspector to review your solar panels and ensure they are working to their full potential.
  • Additional maintenance: If you notice a problem with your solar panels outside of your annual inspection, schedule a solar panels maintenance appointment when necessary.

    Monitoring Solar Power Performance

    A decrease in your panels’ energy output could indicate that your solar power system requires attention. In most cases, your solar panels will not demand maintenance outside of your regular inspections and cleaning, but it’s important to consistently monitor solar panel health.

    The most significant indicator that your solar panels need maintenance is a reduction in your energy output. Keep an eye on your electric bill as an increased bill may highlight a decline in solar energy production – in that case, it’s time to schedule a service appointment.

    How Much Does It Cost per Year?

    We know that installing a solar panel system is a huge investment. As a result, continued costs and maintenance can be disheartening and frustrating. Luckily for panel owners, solar panel maintenance costs will be minimal, meaning you can enjoy sustainable solutions without an ongoing additional expense.

    It’s important to understand that if you give your system a bit of love and care, you will be rewarded with roughly 30 years of solar energy in return. Additionally, a lot of manufacturers will provide a guarantee for any issues that arise within the first 10-25 years. Some providers even include several maintenance visits in your solar panel purchase!

    An annual solar panel service can cost between £100 and £200 a year depending on the provider.

    A further solar panel maintenance cost you need to know about relates to the inverter; the key part of the unit which converts the DC output of your panels into the AC required by your local power grid.

    The inverter has an average lifespan of around 25 years, after which it will need replacing as a cost between £800 and £1,000. While this may seem like a large sum, remember you’re awarding yourself 25 additional years of solar power.

     

    Solar Panel Maintenance Checklist

    We have established that a little solar panel maintenance goes a long way, but how can homeowners keep track of this process. Consider a solar panel maintenance checklist to ensure it is always performing at its best:

    1. Personally examine your solar panels: Check your solar panels 2-4 times per year to ensure they are clean and secure.
    2. Check in on your online monitoring system:Many systems come with a tool / app to track daily output.
    3. Monitor electricity bills:If your electricity bill has gone up, it’s a good sign that you should schedule a service appointment.
    4. Keep a logbook of maintenance:Once per year, hire an inspector to review your solar panels. It is useful to keep a record of maintenance if there are any issues that may need diagnosing in the future.
    5. Replace the inverter:You can expect your inverter to last around 25 years, depending on the model and environmental conditions. Regular inspections can help to determine whether your inverter needs replacing.

      Maintaining Your Solar Panels

      Protecting and caring for your investment is essential to owning any item, and solar panels are no exception. Thankfully, solar panels are incredibly durable and designed to require little to no maintenance. Despite this, regular cleaning and annual inspections will ensure that your panels are performing to the best of their ability year on year.

      If you notice dust, debris or snow piled up on your system, a routine clean will ensure that your panels continue to operate efficiently. Additionally, consider investing in panels with a good warranty so if your panels do break, they’ll get replaced. 

      With these tips, you can keep your solar panels functioning well and producing the power they are designed for. If you have any questions about solar power maintenance and taking care of your system, contact Bluetti today.

WHAT IS A SOLAR GENERATOR?

HOW DOES A SOLAR GENERATOR WORK?

SOLAR PANELS:

  • Solar generators can be acquired with or without solar panels. If you do not have solar panels, you will require to recharge your gadget through another source of power. Although, one of the most reliable means to run a solar generator is by means of solar panels. Your solar panels will convert the sunlight's power into electricity.

INVERTER:

  • Our solar generators all come with the most up-to-date built-in pure sine wave innovation. BATTERY:

WHAT IS A GAS GENERATOR?

A generator transforms kinetic energy (motion) into electrical energy.

A generator typically contains the following components:

  • Engine
  • Alternator
  • Fuel System
  • Voltage Regulator
  • Cooling and Exhaust Systems
  • Lubrication System
  • Battery Charger
  • Control Panel

As you can currently see, when it involves solar generators vs. generators, generators are comprised of a lot more parts. A lot of these components are relocating, and this is the reason gas generators require even more ongoing upkeep.


HOW DOES A GAS GENERATOR WORK?

It transforms kinetic energy (activity) into power. It does this by utilizing a spinning electromagnet (armature) to create an electrical current via a fixed magnetic field (stator). This kinetic energy is normally implemented by shedding either gas or oil.


ENGINE:

  • The engine is where it all begins for the gas generator. It's the source of the input mechanical energy to the generator. The maximum power output of the generator is directly pertaining to the size of the engine. Remember that the maker of the engine should be gotten in touch with to obtain maintenance schedules.


ALTERNATOR:

  • The generator is additionally known as the "genhead" and also is in charge of creating the electric outcome from the mechanical input supplied by the engine. It is made up of fixed and relocating components, which are all framed in housing. All these elements interact to trigger a loved one activity between the magnetic and also electric fields. GAS SYSTEM:

  • The majority of gas storage tanks linked to generators need to have enough capacity to keep the generator functional for 6 to 8 hours typically. Small generators normally have their tanks as part of the skid base or are improved top of the generator's framework.


VOLTAGE REGULATORY AUTHORITY:

  • This component manages the outcome voltage of the gas generator. It virtually does the same thing as the solar generator's inverter. It transforms Air Conditioning to DC and also feeds this to the relevant elements, which cycle it between A/C to DC and DC to AC. This cycle proceeds till the generator is able to generate outcome voltage equal to its full operating capacity.


AIR CONDITIONING & EXHAUST SYSTEM：

  • Freshwater is normally used as a coolant for small generators or very large devices over 2250 kW as well as over. Hydrogen can likewise be used as a coolant for the stator windings of big generator devices. Hydrogen is normally extra efficient at absorbing warmth than other coolants. When it comes to the exhaust, it is unbelievably important that an appropriate system is made use of. Fumes released by a generator are similar to fumes from any other diesel or fuel engine as well as consist of highly poisonous chemicals. Carbon monoxide gas poisoning continues to be among the leading causes of death among blog post-hurricane-impacted areas.


LUBRICATION SYSTEM:

 

  • Unlike solar generators, gas generators consist of many moving components in the engine compartment. Consequently, it needs ample lubrication to guarantee that every little thing continues to be smooth and also durable for an extended period of time. The generator's engine is normally lubed by oil stored in a pump. It is important that once in a while, you inspect the degree of lubrication oil (every 8 hours). You also need to take note of any type of indicator of oil leaks and must transform the engine oil every 500 hrs of generator procedure.


BATTERY CHARGER:

  • Most gas generators' start function is battery operated. The onboard battery charger maintains the generator battery charged by supplying it with an accurate float voltage. If the float voltage is too low, the battery will remain under billed. If it is too high, it will damage the battery. Many battery chargers are completely automatic and do not require any type of changes to be made or any type of settings to be altered.


CONTROL PANEL:

  • This is the user face that is included on a lot of contemporary generators. They likewise include provisions for electric outlets as well as controls. Various suppliers have actually carried user face functions which could consist of electric start as well as shut-down, the engine determines, generator evaluates.


WHICH KINDS OF GENERATORS DO YOU NEED?


We will break this section up into two situations. Each scenario will certainly offer you a basic idea of when each kind of generator will certainly be the most beneficial to you.
